ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

DELIVERY OF HEALTH CARE
(Improvements)


    1. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Health to specify some of the improvements in delivery of health care since the restructuring of hospitals.

     The Senior Minister of State for Health (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, restructuring has brought about many improvements in the delivery of health care service in public hospitals. Some of these improvements include more patient oriented services,

Column: 421

better communication with patients, improvements in patient waiting times, new clinical services and improvements to infrastructure. I would describe a little the improvements in each of these areas.

(i) More Patient Oriented Services

    One significant area of improvement is in the reorganisation and simplification of operational systems, procedures and work flow which have made hospital services more convenient to patients and more responsive to their medical needs. For patients who require admission, a one-stop admission service at ward level has been introduced at Toa Payoh Hospital (TPH) and Singapore General Hospital (SGH). At the outpatient level, specialist outpatient clinics have been reorganised into multi-disciplinary one-stop clinics, eg, Urology Centre, Brain Centre, Heart Centre and Diabetes Centre at SGH; Arthritis Clinic at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and Oncology Centre at Kandang Kerbau Hospital (KKH).

(ii) Better Communication with Patients

    Through an extensive service improvement programme, all hospital frontline staff and supervisors have been trained to be more caring and courteous in their dealings with the public. There has been significant improvement in the way doctors, nurses and counter clerks relate to the patients, their relatives and the public. Financial counselling is routinely provided to all patients and their relatives before admission. Information booklets on hospital services and certain treatment procedures have been made available to patients. This has helped to allay the anxiety of patients before admission or surgery. iii) Improvements in Patient Waiting Times

    There has been a general improvement in waiting times for appointments for surgery and specialist outpatient clinic consultation and waiting times to see the doctor at the specialist outpatient clinics and at the pharmacies to collect medicines.

Column: 422



(iv) New Clinical Services

    New clinical services have been introduced in the hospitals' departments since restructuring. These include Medical Oncology, Neurosurgery and Neurology in SGH, Ear, Nose and Throat and Eye services in TPH, genetic counselling and menopause clinics in KKH, and Podiatry service in TTSH. SGH and TTSH also have walk- in clinics to treat non-emergency patients who would normally have been attended to at the Accident and Emergency (A&E) Department. This has allowed the doctors at the A&E Departments to spend more time on the emergency patients.

(v) Improvements to Infrastructure

    With the opening of ambulatory surgery centres in the hospitals, more patients can now undergo surgery as day patients, thus reducing their hospital cost. New technology such as Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Computerised Tomography (CT) scans have been introduced. The operating theatre and intensive care facilities have been upgraded. Physical improvements have been made to the wards and specialist outpatient clinics in all hospitals so that patients can now enjoy a better ambience and greater comfort as an inpatient or as an outpatient.

    All these improvements have led to a high level of patient satisfaction. In general, more than 90% of feedback from patients have rated the hospital care as good or excellent.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, I want to ask the Senior Minister of State for Health two questions. First, in response to these changes, has the waiting time for medical care improved significantly? Second, has a review been undertaken regarding the access to medical care for the lower income group?

     Dr Aline Wong: As I informed the Member in my general reply, there has been improvement in waiting time. But for specific information on the waiting time by the kind of service, I would appreciate it if he could file a Question and we will give him the detailed breakdown. But

Column: 423

generally, between 1990 and 1995, all the hospitals have seen an improvement in waiting times.

    On the question of access to health care services for the poor, they have always had access to our public sector hospitals. As the Member is well aware, we subsidize B2 and C wards heavily. We have also introduced a new class of ward, B2+, in some hospitals and they are subsidized at 50%. Medifund has been introduced and the number of applicants has actually gone up and the proportion of cases which have been given financial assistance is still very high. I think some 99.6% have been given assistance. So restructuring does not and has not meant a decline in access to good health care at the public sector hospitals.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, have there been any cases which have been denied health care because they are unable to find the funds to get the medical care required?

     Dr Aline Wong: I am not aware of any cases, but if the Member has any case to report, I would be pleased to look into it.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, would the Minister please tell us why there have been so many changes in the manner of paying fees to doctors and how have these differing schemes impacted on the quality of medical care?

     Dr Aline Wong: In the late 1980s and early 1990s, there was a consultancy fee scheme for doctors in the restructured hospitals. The idea was to encourage doctors to improve the quality of service to patients. After a couple of years, we found there were some weaknesses in the system and therefore some changes had been implemented to correct the weaknesses. One of the changes was to introduce the point system in remunerating doctors, so that the doctors earned points irrespective of whether they serviced private patients or subsidized patients.

    The recent feedback is that some doctors find this system not satisfactory either, because they feel that they are

Column: 424

being timed and weighted for every single bit of work they do and they feel that their professionalism has been hindered. Now the hospitals are looking into reforming this system again.

    In reply to the Member, I must say that these changes have been found necessary. If she thinks that there have been too many revisions within a period of a few years, the people on the ground feel that some more changes are necessary because there are weaknesses in the existing system. But whatever system it is, there is always a certain degree of imperfection that we may have to live with.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Would the Minister please confirm that self-referrals, where the patients refer themselves to various specialists instead of being referred by another doctor, are available and how widely are they used?

     Dr Aline Wong: Yes, at the outpatient specialist clinics at the restructured hospitals, it is possible for patients to "walk in" to see a doctor, ie, they can make appointments by themselves to see a doctor. But generally, the bulk of the patients in the restructured hospitals come from referrals.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, would the Minister agree that these self-referrals by patients could lead to unnecessary consumption of medical services and sometimes wrong referrals? So would the Minister consider doing away with self-referrals to consultants and only allowing referrals by other doctors so that there is no unnecessary wastage of medical services?

     Dr Aline Wong: As I said, the proportion of self-referrals is very small. If we were to do away with it, ie, by requiring all patients to have a referral before they can see a specialist in a restructured hospital, then we require altogether a very different system from what we have. We have to think about this proposal carefully and whether this constitutes another form of wastage of resources for the nation. To cut down costs, the patients themselves also have to be educated. They should not just go and see a specialist for a small thing.

Column: 425

But may I suggest to the Member that this question is not really related to the main Question asked by Dr Vasoo.

HDB SALES TRANSACTIONS
(Handling by HDB appointed agents and private individuals)


    2. Mr R. Sinnakaruppan asked the Minister for National Development (a) the rationale for allowing the Housing and Development Board sales transactions handled by appointed agents to be completed in 4 weeks while allowing those transacted by private individuals to take seven weeks and (b) what measures are in place to deal with those appointed agents who misrepresent to the Housing and Development Board on the purchase prices.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB's target for resale transactions by private individuals is five weeks. In other words, private individual applicants will be given their first appointment about five weeks after the submission of their applications, provided they submit all relevant documents and valuation report together with the application form, as in the case of applications submitted by the listed agents.

    Such transactions require one week more than the four-week target for the listed housing agents because HDB will need to do additional checks to ensure that all the documents and valuation reports are in order. In the case of the listed agents, HDB expects these agents to do all these checks before submission to HDB.

    On the second part of the Question, listed housing agencies who are found to have misrepresented the resale prices will be:

    i) prosecuted under the Penal Code for making a false statutory declaration. The penalty is an unlimited fine and a term of imprisonment not exceeding three years;

    ii) debarred from handling resale transactions for a one-year period; and

Column: 426



    iii) dropped from the list. HDB will also publicise the delisting of the agency in the mass media.

     Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, it was reported in the papers last month that the private individual transactions will actually take seven weeks. I am happy to hear now that the target is five weeks. But I really want to understand why there is still a one-week difference. Are we trying to encourage people to go to an agent? A 1% fee for an agent for a flat, say, in Bishan, which is now $770,000, is $7,700. So it is quite significant. Why can we not make it four weeks for private individuals who submit all their documents on time just as in the case of agents? Why do we not make it the same for both cases? Also, can we not make the punishment for private individuals the same as that for the agents?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I explained in my answer, there is additional processing time required by HDB. The agents do provide a certain level of service and because of this additional processing time individuals will require five weeks whereas the listed agents require four weeks. One week does not make that big a difference. In fact, HDB encourages individuals to do the resale transactions on their own. HDB has been running seminars on Saturday afternoons and they intend to run seminars now on every first Saturday of the month. So individuals who are planning to buy or sell resale flats can book into one of these seminars. HDB will explain the procedures clearly and what is required, and they are welcome to do the transactions themselves. But those who want to engage housing agents must be prepared to pay the commission and we hope the housing agents will provide the level of service expected in earning that commission.

     Mr Sinnakaruppan: I agree that one week is not too much of a difference. But I want to make the point that HDB should deal with private individuals as well as agents on equal terms. Let us try and target for four weeks. Secondly, we should publicise what the Minister has said. HDB must publicise more of this to the public

Column: 427

so that they are aware because right now they think that their transactions take seven weeks while it is four weeks for the agents and that the HDB is really trying to encourage them to use the services of the agents.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: That is why we appreciate the Member raising this question here for us to clarify the situation and to explain that HDB does run these seminars. These seminars will also in time be conducted in Mandarin so that the ordinary persons can do these transactions on their own. But if they want to hire an agent, the agent does provide a service by linking a willing buyer and willing seller. We hope the agents would provide that level of service as required.

     Mr Sinnakaruppan: How about my question to allow 4 weeks as well for private individuals?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: As I have explained, there is extra work to be done by HDB when an individual submits an application. Some portion of the work is done by the agent. If an individual does it, he is not doing that segment of the work. So that part is done by HDB, and HDB takes an extra one week.

Column: 427

SIMEX
(Protection against future crises)


    3. Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon asked the Minister for Finance - in the light of the Minister's statement in Parliament on 1st March 1995 that SIMEX would appoint experts from the global futures industry to advise it on protecting itself against future crises like that involving Barings Futures - (a) what recommendations (if any) were made by the experts; (b) whether these recommendations have been implemented by SIMEX; and (c) what other steps (if any) have been taken by SIMEX to prevent a recurrence of the problems that caused the collapse of Barings Futures.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, in March 1995, SIMEX appointed an International Advisory Panel comprising experts from the global

Column: 428

futures industry. They include Dr Wayne Angell, a former member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, Mr John Gilmore, a former Chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, Mr Michael Jenkins, the Chairman of the London Commodity Exchange, Mr Leo Melamed, the former Chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Mr Jack Sandner, its current Chairman. They were appointed to advise on best practices in the futures industry worldwide that could be adopted to improve SIMEX's operations and systems and to enhance customer protection. The Panel concluded its study in October 1995 and made the following recommendations to SIMEX:

    (i) To establish rules and evaluate those in place regarding customer protection with respect to proper margining of positions, segregation and trading floor practices;

    (ii) To upgrade SIMEX clearing policies, systems and procedures to incorporate real-time clearing and settlement and critical risk management systems;

    (iii) To establish confidential information sharing arrangements with mutual offset partners and other exchanges;

    (iv) To establish a requirement for clearing members that a senior officer, who must be in a position of full authority for all business of the firm at SIMEX and related activities on other exchanges, be registered with the Exchange;

    (v) To enhance SIMEX's Market Surveillance Department which is charged with responsibilities including monitoring market positions and their potential impact; and

    (vi) To establish a comprehensive large trader reporting system which will enable the Exchange to determine the ultimate owner of large positions on SIMEX including those maintained in omnibus accounts.

    In April 1995, SIMEX also appointed a consultant, Dr Roger Rutz, the former Chief Executive Officer of the Board of Trading Clearing Corporation, one of the world's largest clearing houses. He was asked to review SIMEX's clearing and

Column: 429

settlement operations and its system for market surveillance so as to improve its clearing and risk management functions. The key measures recommended by the consultant included:

    (i) Establishing a Risk Management Committee to oversee policies on capital requirements, financial and segregation requirements, position limits and reporting and clearing house systems;

    (ii) Improving internal risk analysis procedures to identify accounts and members carrying large positions which may result in substantial losses, and perform tests on these accounts to determine the potential risk to both members and large account holders;

    (iii) Performing detailed analysis of settlements and margin calls on clearing members on a daily basis;

    (iv) Monitoring closely positions carried by clearing members and large accounts which constitute a high percentage of the positions in the market; and

    (v) Upgrading computer systems to provide real-time, on-demand information for clearing processing and risk management.

    SIMEX has adopted all the recommendations made by the Panel and its consultant. It has already implemented the majority of these recommendations and is in the process of implementing the balance, which involve software modifications or rule changes. In line with the recommendations, a new Regulatory and Risk Management Division within SIMEX has been created, comprising the Audit, Floor Compliance, Market Surveillance and Clearing House Departments. Staffing for the division has been strengthened from 48 to 68 members currently, and an eventual total of 78.

    The steps being taken by SIMEX should enable it to monitor its risk exposure to large accounts and take the necessary action to contain these risks. This would minimise systemic risk arising from the failure of a firm having knock-on effects on other participants in the market. However, it should be emphasized that no

Column: 430

regulatory system, however comprehensive, can guarantee that a firm will not fail as a result of fraud or excessive speculative trading.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon (Nominated Member): Sir, there were certain comments made by British authorities in the wake of the Barings collapse that they were not receiving full cooperation from the Singapore side, ie, from SIMEX or other authorities. Would the Minister comment on that?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Who were making the comments?

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: There were some statements made. I believe the Chancellor of the Exchequer did say that.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The comments relate to earlier investigations by the British Serious Fraud Office and by the Bank of England in the early stages of the Barings fiasco. There were legal technicalities which did not allow the Singapore authorities to provide comprehensive information and there was some mis-communication. I think these had been largely settled.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: Sir, now that Mr Leeson has been convicted and sentenced, have the investigations into the Barings matter been closed or can we expect further prosecutions?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Following from the Inspectors' Report, there were suggestions that other people might be involved with Leeson in the fiasco. The Commercial Affairs Department has been pursuing these leads and they are in the process of finalising their report. Let us wait for it. It should not be too long.

RELIGIOUS/QUASI-RELIGIOUS ORGANISATIONS
(Ban)


    4. Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon asked the Minister for Home Affairs how many religious or quasi-religious organisations have been banned in Singapore under the Societies Act or other legislation.

Column: 431



     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, three religious or quasi-religious organisations have been deregistered under the Societies Act.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: Sir, would the Senior Parliamentary Secretary please give details to the House? Which three, and why?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the three organisations are, firstly, the Singapore Congregation of Jehovah's Witnesses (deregistered in January 1972), the Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Christianity or the Unification Church, whose followers are known as the "Moonies", (deregistered in April 1982) and its front organisation, the Moral Home Society (deregistered in July 1990), and the Christian Conference of Asia (deregistered in December 1987).

    Sir, they were deregistered under section 24 of the Societies Act by a Ministerial order on the grounds that their activities were prejudicial to public welfare and good order.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: Sir, could the Senior Parliamentary Secretary give us further details? In what sense were their activities prejudicial to good order?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, in the case of the Jehovah's Witnesses, the group, for example, claims a neutral position in war time. Therefore, this led to a number of its believers in National Service refusing to perform any military duties; some, in fact, refused to wear uniform.

    In the case of the Christian Conference of Asia, the group professed to be a religious organisation but was in actual fact an organisation involved in politics. It encouraged inter-faith dialogues for political ends and involvement of religious organisations in politics.

    In the case of the Moonies, the group brainwashed families and broke them up, and members gave up their possessions to the Church.

Column: 432



    These are examples which illustrate the basis for the ban on these organisations.

     Assoc. Prof. Walter Woon: Sir, would the Senior Parliamentary Secretary reconcile these bans with the constitutional protection on freedom of religion?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, certainly there is freedom of religion in Singapore. Article 15 of our Constitution provides for it. However, Article 15(4) says that, "This Article does not authorise any act contrary to any general law relating to public order, public health or morality".     There is a Chinese saying that there are four essentials in life - yi, shi, zhu, xing - [ ] clothing, food, housing and transport. Singaporeans are well-clothed, well-fed and well-housed. The question is: do they also enjoy a good transport system? I believe I can say with very little fear of contradiction that the answer is yes.

    We have succeeded so far in keeping our roads congestion free. Our bus, rail and taxi network is one of the most comprehensive in the region.

    According to a recent Lianhe Zaobao survey on the lifestyle of Singaporeans, 97% of the 565 respondents said that they were satisfied with the public transport system, 27% said that they were "very satisfied" and 70% "somewhat satisfied".

    Another survey commissioned by the Straits Times Life! section showed similar findings. In its report of 2nd January 1996, it noted that two out of three or 66% of the 538 respondents said that the overall public transport system was "good", 33% found the system "so so", and only 1% reported and rated it "poor". In fact, the level of overall satisfaction reported was higher than that found by Lianhe Zaobao.

    Singaporeans are now more well travelled and they are more well read. They are now more aware of the severe traffic problems in many other cities. So the surveys perhaps reflect a better appreciation of what we do have and what we do enjoy in Singapore. All of us now must be keenly aware that we have not achieved this through doing nothing, simply leaving the vehicle population to grow unmanaged, unrestricted or to leave our public transport system to degenerate.

    Land transport is management intensive. We have to keep on fine-tuning it. We have to keep on coming up with new initiatives in order to ensure that our roads continue to be free-flowing. Even though we do these things, already there are areas where traffic is building up and congestion is getting unacceptably persistent. I still receive lots of complaints about the difficulty of getting taxis. There is still the issue of COE prices and people's aspirations for car-ownership

Column: 471

unfulfilled. These, as they say, are the problems of success, of many years of high economic growth, of full employment and high wages and, more importantly, of confidence in our future. But, if we do not take action now to solve these problems, again they will erode our competitiveness and affect our growth. A good transport system is not an end in itself, but a means to an end. It supports our economy and it enhances our quality of life.

    Sir, the issue before us is how we can, within the constraints of the limited land that we have, provide the best mobility for Singaporeans today, and meet our transport needs into the next century. Members have on many occasions in this House suggested various ways to improve our transport system. I agree with many of their suggestions.

    Considering the importance of land transport to each and everyone of us and to the nation as a whole, and considering its complexity, the issue cannot be dealt with piecemeal. It has to be taken as a whole. Private and public transport policies and measures have to be considered together. They are inter-linked.

    The paradox is that while the car is highly valued partly for its ability to provide a high degree of mobility, an unrestrained growth in the number of cars leads to congestion which in turn means less mobility for all road-users, including the car users. But car users argue that they are not willing to give up the convenience of the car for public transport because it is slow and unreliable. Buses are slow and unreliable, in turn, partly because of congestion. Inefficient and inadequate public transport drives more to want to own and use private cars, and so on it goes, in a vicious circle. The story is a familiar one in many cities around the world. And that is why I say that for this entire transport issue to be addressed, we have to do it in a holistic manner and on a comprehensive basis.

    The White Paper before this House presents the transport planning philosophy and strategies that the LTA will adopt. It spells out the LTA's vision of a world class transport system for Singapore, and it outlines a series of measures that the Authority proposes to take to achieve this mission. Let me just run through the various measures that are encompassed within this multi-pronged strategy.

    First, integrating urban and transport planning. This is the starting point. This is to minimise the need to travel and to maximise the accessibility of public transport. Mixing residential and work places reduces the need to travel long distances and therefore reduces pressure on our road space and transport system.     Second, expanding our road network. Our road network will continue to be expanded where it makes sense from both the traffic as well as the planning point of view and where land is available. The feasibility of underground roads, which are much more expensive to construct and maintain, will be considered. As far as possible, technology will be harnessed to optimise road design and maximise road capacity. That is the second measure.

    Thirdly, improving the management of vehicle usage to sustain higher vehicle population. No matter which way we turn, we cannot escape the fact that land in Singapore is finite, which means that road capacity is finite. Despite our best efforts in maximising the carrying capacity of our roads with new technology and design, ownership of vehicles and usage of limited road space must continue to be managed. The Vehicle Quota System has worked well for us; it has been accepted by Singaporeans. It will be retained. This can be achieved only if we can complement the better transport planning and design with usage management. More comprehensive road pricing will have to be implemented. And this allows road users to make better choices, more informed choices, about when to use and where to use their cars. Conceptually, what this means is that those roads which are more congested will cost more to use and charges can also vary with the time of day, again depending on the level of congestion.

    The last strategy is to improve our public transport system. This is the cornerstone of the land transport strategy. To satisfy the transport needs of commuters and to provide a viable alternative to the car, we need an outstanding public transport system. To do this, the LTA will increase the spectrum of public transport services and service levels, so that Singaporeans can enjoy a wide-ranging, quality transport service that matches their preference and suits their pocket.

    To support our vision for a world class public transport system, the LTA has also

Column: 474

set out to revise the financing formula for rail projects. The revised formula or the redefinition of the current arrangement lowers the hurdle rate, in other words, reduces the passing mark for rail projects.     It is important to realise that even if we have succeeded in implementing the plan as set out in this White Paper, we should not expect a total transformation of our land transport system and that our mobility will improve by quantum leaps. It is because very often, we forget our tremendous land and resource constraint and that Singapore is undergoing constant transformation, population increases, expansion of the city and, even going by a conservative growth rate, tremendous pressure will be exerted on our transportation needs in the future. Therefore, we should view the White Paper from a realistic perspective that if we do not constantly anticipate and find solutions to our transportation requirements in a decade or two, we will suffer the same fate as some other countries are experiencing. We have often quoted examples of travel woes of other places, like Bangkok, Taipei or, even closer home, Malaysia, but always harbour with complacency the thought that it would never happen to Singapore. But the fact remains that given all the constraints, we are more vulnerable and likely to be put in a situation such as those experienced in these countries because of our size and a lack of hinterland. There will always be pressure groups or people like the Opposition, for their own self-interest, to exploit the transport issue by distorting the reality that we face.

    It is well and good to say that we should have a perfect land transport system where mobility is of an optimum level, that we should not wait a minute too long for our buses or taxi, that everyone should be able to own a car, that MRT should be run throughout the island, and areas that cannot be covered by MRT should have a comprehensive and elaborate LRT system. These thoughts are very seductive and appealing, but the reality is that there is no such thing as a perfect land transport system. Mobility is relative. It takes time to travel from one destination to another. It is the amount of time taken to accomplish that which determines how acceptable a country's land transport system is being managed.
